item.title: Harvard Expands Lawsuit Against US as Trump Funding Feud Deepens
item.description: Harvard University expanded its lawsuit Tuesday against the Trump administration for freezing billions of dollars in federal funds, ratcheting up the high-stakes legal battle between the wealthiest US university and the White House.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Janet Lorin

media:content.media:description: Harvard University merchandise displayed at a store in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. President Donald Trump said Harvard University would lose its tax-exempt status, stepping up his attack on the Ivy League school with a threat that was decried as out of his jurisdiction. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: Crypto-Backed Stablecoin Bill Gets Bipartisan Push for Quick Revival in Senate
item.description: Senators in both parties are working to quickly revive stablecoin legislation backed by the crypto industry that faltered after a furor over President Donald Trump’s growing portfolio of lucrative crypto ventures.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Bill Hagerty

item.title: Portugal Far-Right Leader Helped Off Stage After Feeling Unwell
item.description: Portugal’s far-right leader Andre Ventura was helped off the stage during a speech at a campaign dinner on Tuesday, sparking concerns about his health before a snap election due to take place on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: Andre Ventura, leader of Chega, speaks to members of the media at a polling station during the general election in Lisbon, Portugal, on Sunday, March 10, 2024. Portugal is holding early parliamentary elections on Sunday, offering a chance for a far-right party to raise its presence in parliament and upset the country’s two larger traditional centrist powers.

item.title: Trump’s Freebie Qatar Jet Is the Stuff of Nightmares in Spyworld
item.description: Qatar’s offer of a luxury Boeing 747 to President Donald Trump has set off alarm bells within the US intelligence and diplomatic community, where gifts from foreign powers have long been viewed with suspicion.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: The Qatari Boeing 747 at Palm Beach International airport after Trump toured the aircraft on Feb. 15.

item.title: Macron Calls for More Pressure on Israel Over Gaza Actions
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron urged the European Union to step up pressure on Israel over the humanitarian situation in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Friedrich Merz travels to Paris and Warsaw on Wednesday on his first foreign trip as German chancellor, still reeling from a humiliating setback in Tuesday’s government transition that raised early questions about his leadership.

item.title: Trump Puts Dealmaking Over Rights in Saudi Arabia Policy Speech
item.description: President Donald Trump sent a message to the world in Saudi Arabia: make business deals and the US won’t meddle in your affairs.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at Al-Yamamah Palace. Photographer: Win McNamee/Getty Images

item.title: Zelenskiy Stands by Plan to Meet Putin in Turkey for Talks
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy reinforced his intention to hold direct talks with Vladimir Putin in Turkey on Thursday, even though he said he had little hope that the Russian leader would show up.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv, on May 13. Photographer: Evgeniy Maloletka/AP Photo

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Still Weighing on Economy as Recession Risk Fades
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, US economy reporter Jarrell Dillard looks at the headwinds still facing the economy. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

item.title: Peru Surprisingly Changes Finance Minister Ahead of PM Censure Vote
item.description: Peru’s unpopular President Dina Boluarte surprisingly replaced her finance minister who had been on the job less than four months, as the future of her cabinet hangs in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: Raul Perez-Reyes

item.title: How the SALT Fight Threatens to Derail the Republican Tax Bill
item.description: For as long as Americans have paid federal income taxes, they’ve been able to subtract some of what they pay to their state and local governments from their taxable income. This federal deduction for state and local taxes — the SALT deduction, for short — has a big influence on how the tax burden is divided. It tends to help taxpayers in wealthier, more urban states, where sales taxes are higher and real estate costs more. President Donald Trump’s first-term tax law, approved in 2017, capped the
item.dc:creator: Zach C Cohen

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump

item.title: Summers Salutes Bessent on China Deal, Says US Retreat Pragmatic
item.description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers applauded the Trump administration’s walk-back from what he characterized as overly aggressive trade protection measures, singling out Scott Bessent in particular for his weekend work with China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Larry Summers, president emeritus and professor at Harvard University, during a panel session on the closing day of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 16 to 20.

item.title: Jose Mujica, Guerrilla Who Became Uruguay President, Dies at 89
item.description: Jose “Pepe” Mujica, the former left-wing guerrilla who spent more than a decade in prison before becoming president of Uruguay and making it the first country in the world to legalize cannabis, has died. He was 89.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

media:content.media:description: Jose “Pepe” Mujica in 2018.

item.title: US Warns That Using Huawei AI Chip ‘Anywhere’ Breaks Its Rules
item.description: The Commerce Department issued guidance stating that the use of Huawei Technologies Co.’s Ascend artificial intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” violates the government’s export controls, escalating US efforts to curb technological advances in China.
item.dc:creator: Lynn Doan

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. chip.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill to End Duty-Free Imports of Cheap Foreign Goods
item.description: House Republicans have proposed using their giant tax and spending bill to end duty-free imports of cheap foreign goods, a move that would eliminate a perk companies around the world have used to grow their US business for the last decade.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: Packages inside a delivery truck in Beijing.

item.title: Trump Says Fed Must Lower Rates After Soft Inflation Report
item.description: President Donald Trump cited a softer-than-expected inflation report to again pressure Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Augusta Saraiva

item.title: Ukraine, US Sign Additional Documents on Implementing Minerals Deal
item.description: Ukraine and the US have signed additional agreements concerning a natural resources deal, a key demand of US President Donald Trump which is crucial for sustaining military aid for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: A dump truck shifts iron ore from an excavation site near Horishni Plavni, Ukraine.

item.title: SALT Cap Hike Risks Denting Muni Appeal in New York, California
item.description: A long-awaited House bill could dull the allure of municipal bonds in some states by tripling the federal deduction limit to $30,000, even as the legislation looks to keep the securities tax exempt.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: Workers on a construction site repair damage in the Queens borough of New York.

item.title: Romania’s Ultranationalist Endorses Poland’s Nawrocki
item.description: Romanian ultranationalist George Simion attended the election rally of Poland’s opposition candidate Karol Nawrocki five days before the presidential vote in both countries.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: George Simion

item.title: Harvard Feud With Trump Deepens as US Punches Back at Garber
item.description: Harvard University President Alan Garber has twice publicly rebuked the Trump administration for threatening the school’s independence. Both times the US government has punched back.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan, Janet Lorin, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: The Trump administration froze billions of dollars of funds for Harvard University.

item.title: California, New York Sue US Over Funds Tied to Immigration
item.description: California, New York and 18 other states sued the Trump administration, claiming it illegally conditioned billions of dollars in federal funding on immigration enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Malathi Nayak

media:content.media:description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents enter an apartment building during a multi-agency targeted enforcement operation in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Sunday, Jan. 26, 2025. President Donald Trump has pledged to carry out the largest deportation effort in US history, vowing to ultimately deport all of the foreigners living in the country without permission.

item.title: Serbia Detains Ex-Official for Alleged Forgery for Trump Hotel
item.description: Serbian authorities detained a former state official over allegedly forging paperwork to smooth the way for Jared Kushner’s firm to build a luxury hotel and residences in the Balkan country’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A tram rides past the bomb damaged building of the former federal military headquarters in Belgrade on March 19, 2024, which was destroyed 25 years ago during the US-led NATO air campaign against the former Yugoslavia that ended the Kosovo war. The former headquarters of the Yugoslav general staff, bombed by NATO 25 years ago, could be reborn in the form of a luxury hotel financed by the Trump family. (Photo by Andrej ISAKOVIC / AFP) (Photo by ANDREJ ISAKOVIC/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump and MBS Tout $1 Trillion Pledge as Details Remain Elusive
item.description: President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman touted a pledge for $1 trillion in commercial deals in Riyadh on Tuesday, a staggering figure that doesn’t quite stand up to scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Hadriana Lowenkron, Kate Sullivan, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Prince Mohammed bin Salman during a signing ceremony at the Saudi Royal Court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on May 13.

item.title: Trump Vows to Lift Sanctions on Syria in Wake of Assad Fall
item.description: President Donald Trump said he’ll lift US sanctions against Syria following the toppling of former President Bashar al-Assad, a boost to the war-ravaged country’s ambitions of rejoining the international community.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Ahmed al-Sharaa

item.title: Trump Says Rubio Heading to Istanbul for Ukraine-Russia Talks
item.description: President Donald Trump said Secretary of State Marco Rubio and other US officials will go to Istanbul later this week for potential talks between the Russian and Ukrainian leaders, even if there’s still no certainty that Vladimir Putin will show up.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, during a swearing-in ceremony in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Steve Witkoff, US special envoy to the Middle East, is pushing for progress on a deal for Hamas to release the remaining hostages before the end of Trump’s tour of the Middle East, Israel’s Channel 12 reported, a move that would break more than two months of deadlock.

item.title: ‘Bulldog’ Ex-Goldman Banker Answers Carney’s Call to Fix Canada Resources Sector
item.description: The first time Timothy Hodgson was asked by Mark Carney to come to Ottawa, he left behind an investment banking career at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. that had seen him climb the ranks to lead its Canadian business.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo, Christine Dobby

media:content.media:description: Tim Hodgson, managing partner of Alignvest Management Corporation pauses during training camp in Alcove, Quebec on February 8, 2014. A group of bankers and army veterans attended a weekend training camp to prepare them for an upcoming expedition to the Arctic Circle in May, 2014. Cole Burston/Bloomberg.

item.title: Saudi King-in-Waiting Marks Ascent With Gilded Welcome for Trump
item.description: When US President Donald Trump touched down in Riyadh he was greeted by a Saudi leader who was in every respect a king — except for his official title.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at King Khalid International Airport on May 13.

item.title: Carney Puts Ex-Goldman Banker, Quebec Loyalist in Key Jobs
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled his new economic team, keeping longtime politician François-Philippe Champagne as finance minister and placing former Goldman Sachs banker Timothy Hodgson in charge of energy and mining.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, arrives for a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney is set to unveil a new cabinet with many new faces who didn’t serve in Justin Trudeau's inner circle, according to an official with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: Colombian Business Lobby Warns of Risks From a Deal With China
item.description: Colombia’s business lobby warned of risks to local industry from President Gustavo Petro’s plan to join the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro speaks during the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) in Beijing on May 13.

item.title: Trump Says Saudis to Invest $1 Trillion, Touting Deals in the US
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said the kingdom will boost investments in the US to $1 trillion.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 13: U.S. President Donald J. Trump leaves Saudi Royal Court with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on May 13, 2025, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Trump begins a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Reeves Says Never Say Never on Forcing UK Pension Investment
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves said she didn’t rule out mandating pension funds to allocate money to UK assets, as the government seeks to channel more investment into the domestic economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Lizzy Burden, Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves signs the Mansion House Accord in the City of London on May 13.
